methods.saperVedere: Knowing how to see — observation as the foundation of all knowledge
methods.mirrorMind: The painter's mind should be like a mirror, taking the color of whatever it reflects
methods.distanceForJudgment: Step back from your work — distance reveals what closeness conceals
methods.synthesisOfOpposites: Art and science, observation and imagination, are one practice
methods.variationOverRepetition: Nature never makes two things the same — neither should the mind

cognitiveTools: Draw to understand, not just to record
Study anatomy to paint the soul
Find the universal in the particular

passages.text: Learning never exhausts the mind.
Simplicity is the ultimate sophistication.
Study without desire spoils the memory, and it retains nothing that it takes in.
The noblest pleasure is the joy of understanding.
I have been impressed with the urgency of doing. Knowing is not enough; we must apply. Being willing is not enough; we must do.
The painter has the universe in his mind and hands.
There are three classes of people: those who see, those who see when they are shown, those who do not see.
Water is the driving force of all nature.
In rivers, the water that you touch is the last of what has passed and the first of that which comes; so with present time.
Art is never finished, only abandoned.
The greatest deception men suffer is from their own opinions.
Nature is the source of all true knowledge. She has her own logic, her own laws.
The eye, which is called the window of the soul, is the principal means by which the central sense can most completely and abundantly appreciate the infinite works of nature.
I love those who can smile in trouble, who can gather strength from distress, and grow brave by reflection.
Nothing strengthens authority so much as silence.
Once you have tasted flight, you will forever walk the earth with your eyes turned skyward.
Time stays long enough for anyone who will use it.
Where the spirit does not work with the hand, there is no art.
All our knowledge has its origins in our perceptions.
Every now and then go away, have a little relaxation, for when you come back to your work your judgment will be surer.
Experience is never at fault; it is only your judgment that is in error in promising itself results which are not caused by your experiments.
passages.context: Experience as bedrock — our interpretation fails, not the data

passages.text: Whoever in discussion adduces authority uses not intellect but rather memory.
The supreme misfortune is when theory outstrips performance.
Poor is the pupil who does not surpass his master.
Nature is full of infinite causes which were never set forth in experience.
The mind of the painter should be like a mirror which always takes the colour of the thing that it reflects.
If you are alone you belong entirely to yourself; if you are accompanied even by one companion you belong only half to yourself.
passages.context: The cost of companionship on concentration

passages.text: The soul desires to dwell in the body because without the body it can neither act nor feel.
Tears come from the heart and not from the brain.
Man and the animals are merely a passage and channel for food, a tomb for other animals, a haven for the dead.
passages.context: Human as biological process, not exception

passages.text: The painter is not worthy of praise who only does one thing well.
Do you not see how many and how varied are the actions which are performed by men alone? Do you not see how many different kinds of animals there are, and also of trees and plants and flowers?
If you but know well how to compose your picture it will also seem a natural thing seen in a great mirror.
passages.context: Art succeeds when it achieves the clarity of reflection

passages.text: We know well that mistakes are more easily detected in the works of others than in one's own.
That figure is most worthy of praise which by its action best expresses the passion which animates it.
passages.context: Truth in art is truth of inner life

fables.title: The Willow and the Gourd
fables.summary: A willow, tired of being pruned for other trees, allies with a gourd which eventually strangles her. When the wind comes, she is torn apart.
fables.moral: The alliance you seek for freedom may become your bondage.

fables.title: The Razor
fables.summary: A razor, proud of its shine, refuses to work and hides away. In time it rusts and becomes useless.
fables.moral: Gifts unused corrode. The rust of idleness is worse than the wear of use.

fables.title: The Stone on the Hill
fables.summary: A stone on a beautiful hilltop, envying the company of stones below, throws itself down to join them. There it is trampled endlessly by carts and feet.
fables.moral: What looks like isolation may be sanctuary. What looks like company may be suffering.

fables.title: The Butterfly and the Flame
fables.summary: A butterfly, drawn by a flame's beauty, burns its wings. Returning again, it is consumed entirely.
fables.moral: Not everything beautiful is safe. Some attractions are designed to destroy.

fables.title: The Flint
fables.summary: A flint, struck by steel, protests the violence. The steel replies: be patient. The flint endures and gives birth to fire.
fables.moral: What feels like violence may be the force that awakens your hidden gift.

fables.title: The Nut in the Wall
fables.summary: A nut, dropped by a crow into a wall crevice, begs the wall for shelter. The wall agrees. But the nut's roots eventually tear the wall apart.
fables.moral: Compassion has consequences. What you shelter may outgrow the shelter.

prophecies.meaning: Communication technology — letters, eventually phones, internet
prophecies.method: Defamiliarization of the ordinary through cosmic framing

prophecies.riddle: The dead shall come forth from under the earth, and by their fierce movements shall drive out of the world innumerable human creatures.
prophecies.method: Treating mundane materials as mythic agents
